case_name: Oriental Metal Pressing Works Ltd., Govind and Bhalchandra v. Bhaskar and Harish

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 10 of 1960 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 24, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 540 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 10 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 24, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 540 of 1958.

facts.text: Dadoba Tukaram Thakoor carried on a business under the name and style of Oriental Metal Pressing Works.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-Dadoba Tukaram Thakoor carried on a business under the name and style of Oriental Metal Pressing Works.

facts.text: On May 26, 1955, a private company was incorporated under the name of Oriental Metal Pressing Works Ltd. to take over the aforesaid business.

anchor.surface_text: On May 26,1955, a private companypany was incorporated under the name of Oriental Metal Pressing Works Ltd., hereafter called the Company, to take over the aforesaid business.

facts.text: On July 7, 1955, Dadoba transferred his business to the Company.

anchor.surface_text: On July 7, 1955, Dadoba transferred his business to the Company.

facts.text: On July 7, 1955, an agreement was made between Dadoba and the Company by which he was appointed the managing director for life and given power to appoint successor by deed inter vivos, will or codicil.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date, an agreement was made between him and the Company by which he was appointed the managing director of the Company for life and was given the power by deed inter vivos or by will or companyicil to appoint any person to be a managing director in his place and stead.

facts.text: Regulation 109 of the articles of the Company reproduced the provisions of the agreement regarding appointment as MD and power to appoint successor.

anchor.surface_text: Regulation 109 of the articles of the Company reproduced these provisions.

facts.text: Shareholders of the Company were Dadoba, his brother Bhaskar (respondent), and his sons Govind (appellant) and Harish (respondent).

anchor.surface_text: The shareholders of the Company were Dadoba, his brother, the respondent Bhaskar, and his two sons, the appellant Govind and the respondent Harish, of whom the first three were the directors, Dadoba being the managing director.

facts.text: Dadoba, Bhaskar and Govind were the directors, with Dadoba as managing director.

anchor.surface_text: ...the appellant Govind and the respondent Harish, of whom the first three were the directors, Dadoba being the managing director.

facts.text: This constitution of the Company continued till Dadoba's death on January 14, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: This companystitution of the Company companytinued till Dadobas death on January 14, 1957.

facts.text: Dadoba left a will whereby he appointed appellant Govind as managing director from the date of his death.

anchor.surface_text: Dadoba had died leaving a will whereby he purported to appoint the appellant Govind the managing director of the Company in his place from the date of his death.

facts.text: Shortly after Dadoba's death, disputes arose between appellant Govind and respondent Bhaskar.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly after Dadobas death, disputes arose between the appellant Govind and the respondent Bhaskar.

facts.text: Appellant Govind contended that respondent Bhaskar had ceased to be a director due to failure to attend directors' meetings.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Govind was companytending that the respondent Bhaskar had ceased to be a director on account of his failure to attend the directors meetings.

facts.text: Appellant Govind purported to appoint appellant Bhalchandra as a director.

anchor.surface_text: He also purported to companyopt the appellant Bhal- chandra as a director.

facts.text: Respondent Bhaskar contended he had not ceased to be a director, challenged Bhalchandra's appointment as illegal, and that Govind's MD appointment by will was void.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Bhaskar companytended that be had number ceased to be a director and challenged the legality of the appointment of the appellant Bhalchandra as a director. He further companytended that the appointment of the appellant Govind as the managing director of the Company by the will of Dadoba, was void.

facts.text: On November 22, 1957, respondent Bhaskar filed a suit in the City Civil Court of Bombay against the Company, appellants Govind and Bhalchandra, and respondent Harish.

anchor.surface_text: On November 22, 1957, the respondent Bhaskar filed a suit in the City Civil Court of Bombay against the Company, the appellants Govind and Bhalchandra and the respondent Harish for the following declarations...

facts.text: Bhaskar sought declarations that Govind's MD appointment was void, Bhalchandra's directorship illegal, and he (Bhaskar) continued as director.

anchor.surface_text: ...for the following declarations and for reliefs incidental thereto  a the appointment of the appellant Govind as the managing director was void  b the appointment of the appellant Bhalchandra as director was illegal and inoperative and  c he  the respondent Bhaskar  was and companytinued to be a director.

facts.text: City Civil Court Judge accepted all contentions of Bhaskar and made the declarations.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge of the City Civil Court accepted all the companytentions of the respondent Bhaskar and made the declarations claimed.

facts.text: Company and appellants Govind and Bhalchandra appealed to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Company and the appellants Govind and Bhalchandra appealed from this decision to the High Court at Bombay.

facts.text: Bombay High Court bench of two judges took different views, matter referred to third judge; majority dismissed appeal and confirmed City Civil Court decree.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal came up for hearing before a bench of two learned Judges of that Court. These learned Judges having taken different views, the matter was referred to another learned Judge of the same High Court. In the eventual result...

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court however granted a certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution and the present appeal has been filed by the Company, Govind and Balchandra pursuant thereto.

facts.text: While appeal pending in Supreme Court, Bhaskar sold his holding to Govind and has no interest in Company or appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that while the appeal was pending in this Court, the respondent Bhaskar sold his holding in the Company to the appellant Govind and has number numberinterest in the Company or the appeal.

facts.text: Respondent Harish did not appear to contest the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: No one has companysequently appeared to companytest the appeal in this Court, the respondent Harish apparently number being interested in doing so.

facts.text: Issues whether Bhaskar continues as director and Bhalchandra legally appointed are no longer live and not canvassed.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the questions whether the respondent Bhaskar companytinues to be a director and whether the appellant Bhalchandra was legally companyopted as a director are numberlonger live issues and have number been canvassed in this appeal.

facts.text: Courts below held appointment of Govind as MD by Dadoba's will void under s.312 Companies Act 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below held that the appointment of the appellant Govind as managing director by the will of Dadoba was void in view of the provisions of s. 312 of the Companies Act, 1956.

facts.text: Companies Act 1956 came into force on April 1, 1956; Dadoba made will and died after that date.

anchor.surface_text: The Act came into force on April 1, 1956 and Dadoba had both made his will and died, after that date.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that appointment by will is not an 'assignment of office' under s.312 and is valid.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the appellant Govind had been lawfully and validly appointed the managing director of the Company.

facts.text: Supreme Court declares Govind validly appointed MD and sets aside lower courts' decisions.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, declare that the appellant Govind had been validly appointed the managing director of the Company, and set aside the decisions of the Courts below that he had number been so appointed.
The High Court however granted a certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution and the present appeal has been filed by

issues.text: Whether the High Court was right in holding that the word 'assignment' in s. 312 included 'appointment' making such appointment void

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, took the view that the word assignment in the section included appointment, and so, such an appointment would also be void under the section. What we have to decide is whether the High Court was right in this view.

holdings.text: on a plain reading of the language used in the section, it does not seem to us possible to hold that the word assignment in it, can mean appointment.

anchor.surface_text: But on a plain reading of the language used in the section, it does not seem to us possible to hold that the word assignment in it, can mean appointment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain meaning: 'assignment of his office' implies transfer of existing office held at time ('his'), not appointment to vacancy; transfer and appointment are distinct acts.

holdings.text: It will not be right so to interpret s. 312, when its language does not compel it, as to bring in conflict with the provisions of s. 255.

anchor.surface_text: It will not be right so to interpret s. 312, when its language does not compel it, as to bring in conflict with the provisions of s. 255.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.255 expressly permits articles to allow appointment of directors (including successors) otherwise than by company meeting; s.312 cannot override this without textual compulsion.

holdings.text: the object of the Act or of s. 312 [is not] to prevent a director from appointing his successor.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore unable to agree that it was the object of the Act or of s. 312 to prevent a director from appointing his successor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.255 permits perpetual management via articles in private companies; ss.254,317 do not prohibit; Act policy ensures shareholder choice for company-appointed directors, not article-appointed.

holdings.text: the proviso to s. 86B of the old Act does not assist the argument that in s. 312 of the new Act, the word assignment would include appointment.

anchor.surface_text: It is a well established principle of construction that when one finds a proviso to a section, the presumption is that but for the proviso the enacting part of the section would have included the subject matter of the proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso presumption limited to alternate directors; s.313 now independent; old s.83B like new s.255 permits such appointments; cannot imply general inclusion.

holdings.text: It follows that the appellant Govind had been lawfully and validly appointed the managing director of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the appellant Govind had been lawfully and validly appointed the managing director of the Company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointment by will under articles/reg.109 valid per s.255; not 'assignment' under s.312.

holdings.text: We, therefore, declare that the appellant Govind had been validly appointed the managing director of the Company, and set aside the decisions of the Courts below that he had not been so appointed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts erred in holding void under s.312.

holdings.text: We have not been asked to interfere with the rest of the judgment under appeal and we do not do so.

precedents.cited_proposition: if the language of the enacting part of the statute does not contain the provisions which are said to occur in it, you cannot derive these provisions by implication from a proviso.
